revision.comment: /* Tallest buildings in Downtown Louisville */
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2016}} [[File:Louisville, Kentucky skyline - April 2011.jpg|thumb|right|350px|The Louisville skyline]] '''Downtown Louisville''' is the largest [[central business district]] in the Commonwealth of [[Kentucky]] and the urban hub of the [[Louisville, Kentucky]] Metropolitan Area. Its boundaries are the [[Ohio River]] to the north, Hancock Street to the east, York and Jacob Streets to the south, and 9th Street to the west. As of 2015, the population of Downtown Louisville was 4,700, although this does not include directly surrounding areas such as Old Louisville, Butchertown, NuLu,and Phoenix Hill. The five main areas of the [[Central Business District]] consist of: *'''[[West Main District, Louisville|West Main District]]''' (west of 2nd St., north of Market St., east of 9th St., and south of the [[Ohio River]]) *'''East Main District''' (east of 2nd St., north of Market St., west of Hancock St., and south of the Ohio River; contains the [[Whiskey Row, Louisville|Whiskey Row Historic District]]) *'''Medical Center''' (east of 2nd St., south of Market St., west of Hancock St., and north of Jacob St.) *'''Fourth St. District''' (south of Market St., west of 2nd St., north of York St., and east of 5th St.) *'''Civic Center''' (south of Market St., west of 5th St., north of York St., and east of 9th St.) The [[tallest buildings by states|tallest buildings]] in Kentucky are located in Downtown Louisville and include [[400 West Market]] designed by [[John Burgee]], [[National City Tower]] designed by [[Wallace Harrison|Harrison]] & [[Max Abramovitz|Abramovitz]], [[PNC Plaza]] designed by [[Welton Becket]], and the [[Humana Building]] designed by [[Michael Graves]]. Of the 16 buildings in Kentucky over {{convert|300|ft|m}}, 12 are in Downtown Louisville. In addition, it is the center of local and regional government. [[File:AEGON Center.JPG|thumb|right|200px|[[400 West Market]]]] A glassed-in [[skywalk]] called the Louie Link stretches six city blocks and links together the [[Kentucky International Convention Center]] (KICC), [[Fourth Street Live!]], three hotels ([[Galt House|Galt House Hotel & Suites]], [[Marriott International|Marriott]] and [[Hyatt|Hyatt Regency]]), and 2,300 hotel rooms. In 2010 it was extended from the [[Galt House]] to the new $16 million Skywalk Garage, an eight-level, 860-space parking facility on Third Street, and a second skywalk connects from the garage across Third Street to the new [[KFC Yum! Center]]. ==History== {{See also|History of Louisville, Kentucky}} [[File:Levy building louisville.jpg|thumb|200px|The Richardsonian Romanesque Levy Building, built in 1893, is an example of Downtown Louisville's classic architecture, as well as its revitalization; the upper four floors have been converted to 23 loft condominiums.]] Downtown Louisville is the oldest part of the city of Louisville, whose initial development was closely tied to the [[Ohio River]]. The largest early fort, [[Fort Nelson (Kentucky)|Fort Nelson]], was built in 1781 near what is today the corner of 7th and Main streets. Many early residents lived nearby after moving out of the forts by the mid-1780s, although little remains of the earliest (mostly wood) structures. Early plans of the city, such as William Pope's original plan in 1783, show a simple grid on an east/west axis along the river. The earliest streets, Main, Market and Jefferson retain their original names from the plan, while the smaller Green Street is now known as Liberty (it was renamed after Green Street acquired a seedy reputation due to its many burlesque theaters). Main Street was the city's initial commercial hub for nearly a century. By 1830 Louisville passed [[Lexington, Kentucky|Lexington]] as Kentucky's largest city, with a population over 10,000. The [[steamboat]] era saw the opening of the [[Louisville and Portland Canal]] just west of downtown, and local commerce picked up further with the founding of banks and manufacturing. Most of Louisville's population was packed into downtown, which by this time stretched as far south as Prather Street (later renamed Broadway). Many still-remaining buildings reveal what the area was like at this time, with narrow, two to four-story buildings packing the streets. The area and the city continued to grow during the railroad era. However, the increased mobility of early [[tram|trolleys]], as well as the sheer number and diversity of people moving to Louisville, saw a shift in focus as areas like [[Phoenix Hill]], [[Russell, Louisville|Russell]] and what is now [[Old Louisville]] began to be built on the edges of downtown, particularly after the city [[annexation|annexed]] those areas in 1868. Railroads lead to a diminished role for the river in transportation, further reducing the importance of downtown in favor of areas on what was then the edge of the city, along rail lines. In 1886, the first skyscraper,{{cite journal|url=http://www.aia-ckc.org/download.php?tn=mod_downloads_1&pk=fileid&id=138 |title=History of Louisville Architectural Firms |author=Wiser, Stephen A. |accessdate=April 28, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208072024/http://www.aia-ckc.org/download.php?tn=mod_downloads_1&pk=fileid&id=138 |archivedate=February 8, 2012 }} the Kenyon Building, was completed on Fifth Street, followed in 1890 by the ten-story [[Columbia Building (Louisville, Kentucky)|Columbia Building]]. The development of three large suburban parks and the electrified [[streetcar]] lead to the first true movement to the suburbs at this time. Some of downtown's business and industry followed people toward these areas. But by the 1920s the commercial center of Louisville was still nearby, at 4th and Broadway, dubbed the "magic corner" by the ''[[Louisville Herald-Post|Herald-Post]]''. The riverfront area of downtown was still being actively improved, such as with the building of what is now [[George Rogers Clark Memorial Bridge]] across the Ohio at Second Street in 1929. After [[World War II]], suburbanization increased and downtown began to decline as interstate highways further reduced the importance of its central location. Since the 1970s, downtown has been the subject of both [[urban renewal]] and [[historic preservation]] efforts. While many new buildings have been built, it has sometimes been at the expense of older landmarks, such as the [[Tyler Block]]. Many buildings sat totally or mostly vacant at this time, and some became dilapidated to the point where they burned down or had to be razed. Many riverfront industrial sites were abandoned or saw limited use, many were eventually redeveloped into [[Louisville Waterfront Park]]. Other issues in the 1970s through the early 1990s included a former theater district on Jefferson Street that had become dubbed the "porno district". The businesses there were seen by the city as an eyesore since they were so close to the convention center, and most were demolished or burned down by the late 1990s. A few adult book stores and bars remained in the general area as of 2007. From the late 1970s to early 1990s, nine new high rises over {{convert|200|ft|m}} in height were built in downtown. Unlike the city's previous tallest buildings, which were all set along the Broadway corridor, these new buildings were set closer to the riverfront along Main and Market Streets. Since 2000, downtown has seen another major growth spurt, although this one not only includes new high rises, but also a large scale return of large scale residential and retail back to the city center. The completion of [[Louisville Slugger Field]] along with a mass expansion of the city's [[Louisville Waterfront Park|Waterfront Park]], both completed in 1998, sparked new development along the eastern edge of downtown, with entire abandoned blocks rebuilt with new condominium units and shops. Also, new to Louisville is the 22,000-seat [[KFC Yum! Center]] at Second and Main Streets which was completed in 2010. Image:Columbia-building.jpg|The [[Columbia Building (Louisville, Kentucky)|Columbia Building]], Louisville's second skyscraper Image:The Brown Hotel, Louisville, KY.jpg|The [[Brown Hotel (Louisville, Kentucky)|Brown Hotel]] (built 1923) Image:Heyburn side.jpg|The [[Heyburn Building]] (built 1928) ==Residential== [[File:Pendennis club c1906.jpg|thumb|Example of an early downtown mansion, this Walnut Street mansion was built by the Belknap family and used as the first clubhouse of the [[Pendennis Club]] before being razed]] Early residences outside of the forts, still mostly wood structures, were built along the modern street grid on early lots sold to settlers, but have all been demolished over time. What became the almost entirely office and parking-lot dominated downtown still had many solidly single family residential blocks on its fringes up until the early 20th century. Streets near Broadway, such as Chestnut, were lined with large mansions of the owners of businesses on Main and Market streets. [[File:Louemaindev.jpg|thumb|left|New development on East Main Street]] Though these houses were built of brick and other longer-lasting materials, none remained single family homes by the 21st century, although some had been converted for other uses, such as office space. The [[Ronald-Brennan House|Brennan House]] at 631 S. Fifth, which is operated as a historic property with daily tours, shows a glimpse of Downtown Louisville's residential past. A structure at 432 South Fifth Street is the only example of a pre-Civil War residence remaining Downtown; built in 1829 it has been converted to commercial use.''Louisville Guide'' (2004), p. 136 By the late 20th century, downtown Louisville had acquired a reputation as a place to work and visit during the week but which shuts down evenings and weekends. The first changes to this were the conversion of old warehouse and factory space to loft apartments in the late 1980s. By the late 1990s and early 2000s, new developments of luxury condominiums such as the 22-story ''Waterfront Park Place'', and the $30 million project ''Fleur de Lis on Main'', indicate increasing residential interest in Downtown Louisville. On September 9, 2013, Mayor Greg Fischer joined groundbreaking ceremonies for the second phase of ''RiverPark Place'', a marina apartment/condominium development covering 40 acres along River Road, with a walkway west to [[Louisville Waterfront Park|Waterfront Park]].{{cite news |url= http://www.louisvilleky.gov/economicdevelopment/News/2013/OfficialsBreakGroundforExpandedRiverParkPlace.htm |title= Officials Break Ground for Expanded River Park Place – Louisville.gov |date= September 9, 2013 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20130924222717/http://www.louisvilleky.gov/economicdevelopment/News/2013/OfficialsBreakGroundforExpandedRiverParkPlace.htm |archivedate= September 24, 2013 |df= mdy-all }} In 1997, the [[Kentucky Towers]] was the largest residential building in Downtown Louisville,{{cite book|last1=Nold|first1=Chip|last2=Bahr|first2=Bob|title=Insiders' Guide to Louisville, Kentucky & Southern Indiana, 2nd|url=https://books.google.com/?id=LEOE3_1PUgwC&pg=PA278&dq=%22kentucky+towers%22#v=onepage&q=%22kentucky%20towers%22&f=false|year=1997|publisher=Globe Pequot|isbn=978-1-57380-043-3|page=278|accessdate=October 22, 2010}} and in 2015, just south of downtown, [[The 800 Apartments]] started undergoing a more than $10 million modernization.{{cite news|url= http://www.bizjournals.com/louisville/news/2015/06/19/800-apartments.html |title= Village Green CEO: 800 Apartments 'will be the best apartment building in Louisville' |work=Louisville Business First |date=June 19, 2015 |accessdate=June 3, 2016}} In 2007 Downtown Louisville became Jefferson County's tenth [[Multiple Listing Service]] zone. [[File:Loulibertygreens.jpg|thumb|right|Liberty Greens will contain over 600 [[mixed-income housing]] units]] Housing units available downtown were expected to double between 2005 and 2010, from 1,800 to nearly 4,000, after increasing by only 900 units from 1985 to 2005.{{cite web|archivedate=October 1, 2006 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061001202622/http://www.louisvilleky.gov/DowntownDevelopment/News/2006/DowntownActivity.htm |title=LouisvilleKy.gov - 2006 - Louisville's Downtown Alive with Development |publisher=louisvilleky.gov |date=October 1, 2006 |accessdate=December 6, 2011|url=http://www.louisvilleky.gov/DowntownDevelopment/News/2006/DowntownActivity.htm }} This is both a result of new condominium construction and efforts to convert existing buildings into mixed usage, such as the $20 million redevelopment of the historic eight-story ''Henry Clay'' building at Third and Chestnut streets into a mix of residential, restaurant, retail and event space. The redevelopment also includes property that extends east to Fourth Street, which will become a public piazza, and the historic ''Wright-Taylor'' building, a two-story, {{convert|13500|sqft|m2|sing=on}} structure that faces Fourth Street and is located behind the Henry Clay, and is now an upscale restaurant that occupies the entire Wright-Taylor building. ==Plans== Projects in the works include the construction of a wharf along the [[Riverwalk Trail]], and the [[Ohio River Bridges Project]], involving the reconstruction of [[Kennedy Interchange|Spaghetti Junction]] (the intersection of [[Interstate 65|I-65]], [[Interstate 64|I-64]] and [[Interstate 71|I-71]]) along with the addition of a new bridge for northbound I-65 traffic. One recently completed project was the conversion of the former [[Big Four Bridge|Big Four railroad bridge]] into a pedestrian and bicycle only bridge, which opened on the Kentucky side in 2013 and the Indiana side in 2014. On August 19, 2007, city leaders and the [[Cordish Company]], developers of [[4th Street Live!]], announced ''Center City'', a $442 million, multi-year plan to develop {{convert|23|acre|m2}}, bounded by Second, Third and Liberty streets and Muhammad Ali Boulevard, that will include new housing, restaurants, a cinema and a boutique hotel. An estimated {{convert|500000|sqft|m2}} of floor space being created, including a 15-story structure. As the plan would require $130 million in local and state tax rebates for Cordish, it requires approval from the [[Louisville Metro Council]] and [[Kentucky General Assembly]]. There is no official start time for the project, as financing is still being secured by the Cordish Company.{{cite news |title=More in store for downtown |publisher=[[The Courier-Journal]] |date=August 19, 2007 |author=Davis, Alex |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courier_journal/access/1724595761.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+19%2C+2007&author=&pub=Courier+-+Journal&edition=&startpage=A.1&desc=More+in+store+for+downtown}} Also announced in 2007, the glass and steel $50 million shopping and office complex ''Iron Quarter'' was to be constructed within the [[Whiskey Row, Louisville|Whiskey Row Historic District]], but the project was delayed and eventually set aside when property owner Todd Blue made an agreement with the city of Louisville in January 2011 to demolish the seven original buildings. In May 2011, after all seven buildings had been landmarked, a new agreement was made with the city to save five of the seven buildings by donating one and selling the other four, with the remaining two to be demolished. Facades of all seven buildings are to be preserved.{{cite web|url=http://www.louisvilleky.gov/Mayor/News/2011/5-9-11+whsikey+row+saved.htm |title=Fischer Announces Plans to Preserve Historic Whiskey Row |publisher=LouisvilleKY.gov |date=May 9, 2011 |accessdate=December 6, 2011}} ==Attractions== {{See also|List of attractions and events in the Louisville metropolitan area}} Many attractions are located in Downtown Louisville. * "Museum Row" in the [[West Main District (Louisville)|West Main District]] ** [[Frazier History Museum]] ** [[Kentucky Museum of Art and Craft]] ** [[Kentucky Science Center]] ** [[Louisville Slugger Museum & Factory]] ** [[Muhammad Ali Center]] ** [[Sons of the American Revolution|National Society of the Sons of the American Revolution]] Genealogical Research Library{{cite web |url=http://library.sar.org/ |title=SAR Genealogical Research Library |website=National Society Sons of the American Revolution |accessdate=October 21, 2015}} * [[East Market District, Louisville|East Market District]], featuring a row of art galleries, prominently featured in the monthly [https://web.archive.org/web/20030506084827/http://www.nfb.org/bm/bm03/bm0304/bm030405.htm First Friday Trolley Hop] * [[Belle of Louisville]] * [[Early Times]] Distillery * [[Fort Nelson (Kentucky)|Fort Nelson Park]] * [[Fourth Street Live!]] * [[The Kentucky Center]] * [[Louisville Extreme Park]] * [[Louisville Slugger Field]] (Home of the [[Louisville Bats]] and [[Louisville City FC]]) * [[Louisville Waterfront Park|Waterfront Park]] * [[Riverfront Plaza/Belvedere]] * [[KFC Yum! Center]] (Home of [[Louisville Cardinals]] [[Louisville Cardinals men's basketball|men's]] and women's basketball, plus women's volleyball) File:Louisville Fourthstreetlive.jpg|[[Fourth Street Live!]] File:Thunder over louisville 2006.jpg|[[Thunder Over Louisville]] File:LouisvilleSluggerMusem.jpg|[[Louisville Slugger Museum & Factory]] File:Louisville Skatepark-night-2002.jpg|[[Louisville Extreme Park]] File:AliCenter.jpg|[[Muhammad Ali Center]] File:FIHM.jpg|[[Frazier History Museum]] File:LouisvilleGlassworks.jpg|[[Louisville Glassworks]] Museum and Artists Studio File:KFC Yum! Center.jpg|[[KFC Yum! Center]] ==Images== ===Modern high rises=== File:Louisville sistercities.jpg|The distances to each of Louisville's sister cities are represented on this lightpost downtown. File:LouisvilleSkyscrapers.jpg|Many of Louisville's skyscrapers, from left: The [[Humana Building]], [[National City Tower]], [[LG&E]] Center (distant) and [[400 West Market]] File:Aegoncenterlou.jpg|[[400 West Market]], Kentucky's tallest building since 1993 File:PNC Plaza.JPG|PNC Tower File:Twintowerslou.jpg|Waterfront Plaza I & II File:Loumaindev1.jpg|Top Left: Waterfront Park Place (2004), Right: Preston Pointe (2004) File:Jewishopstowers.jpg|Jewish Hospital Medical Towers File:Loudwntmotels.jpg|The Marriott and Hyatt Regency Hotels in Downtown File:Ulmedconstr.jpg|Construction on medical research building at Hancock and Liberty Streets File:Newmotellou.jpg|Construction on new hotel complex, Preston and Liberty Streets File:Omni Louisville Construction.jpg|The [[Omni Louisville Hotel]] under construction in August 2017, completed March 2018 ==Tallest buildings in Downtown Louisville== {{See also|List of tallest buildings in Louisville}} {| class="wikitable" style="width:100%;" |- ! [[Louisville Metro Housing Authority|Metro Housing Authority]] | | 18 | 1968 | Completed |- | 20th | Kentucky Home Life Building | 235 ft (71.6 m) | 19 | 1913 | Completed |- | 21st | [[Brown Hotel (Louisville, Kentucky)|Brown Hotel]] | | 16 | 1923 | Completed |- | 22nd | [[Kentucky Towers]] | 202 ft (61.5 m) | 18 | 1924 | Completed |- | 23rd | [[Starks Building]] | 202 ft (61.5 m) | 14 | 1913 | Completed |- | 24th | [[River View Place]] | 201 ft (61 m) | 19 | 1925 |- | 25th | [[Marriott Louisville]] | 200 ft (61 m) | 17 | 2005 | Completed |- | 26th | [[ZirMed Gateway Towers]] | | 12 | 2009 | Completed |} ==See also== * [[Cityscape of Louisville, Kentucky]] * [[Geography of Louisville, Kentucky]] * [[Ohio River Bridges Project]] * [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Downtown Louisville, Kentucky]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{cite book | first = George H. | last = Yater | year = 1987 | title = Two Hundred Years at the Falls of the Ohio: A History of Louisville and Jefferson County | publisher = [[The Filson Historical Society|Filson Club, Incorporated]] | edition = 2nd | isbn = 0-9601072-3-1 }} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20030506084827/http://www.nfb.org/bm/bm03/bm0304/bm030405.htm Louisville Downtown Partnership] ** [http://www.louisvilledowntown.org/maps/ Downtown Maps] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120205195757/http://www.ecentral.com/louisvillemaps/central_business_district.gif Street Map of Downtown Louisville] * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030506084827/http://www.nfb.org/bm/bm03/bm0304/bm030405.htm |date=May 6, 2003 |title=Getting around Downtown Louisville }} * [http://www.emporis.com/statistics/tallest-buildings/city/101641/louisville-ky-usa Emporis - revision.text:
{{good article}} {{good article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2013}} [[File:Jerusalem triangle.jpg|250px|right|thumb|Aerial view of Jerusalem's Downtown Triangle.]] The '''Downtown Triangle''' ({{lang-he|המשולש}}, ''Ha-Meshulash'', lit. "The Triangle") is a central commercial and entertainment district in [[West Jerusalem|Western]] [[Jerusalem]]. Measuring {{convert|29000|sqm}},{{cite web |url=http://jerusalem.com/articles/jerusalem/the_jerusalem_triangle-a4166|title=The Jerusalem Triangle|publisher=Jerusalem.com|date=5 July 2013|accessdate=24 November 2013}} the area is bounded by [[Jaffa Road]] on the north, [[King George Street (Jerusalem)|King George Street]] on the west, and [[Ben Yehuda Street (Jerusalem)|Ben Yehuda Street]] on the southeast. Its [[Vertex (geometry)|vertices]] are the intersections of Jaffa Road and King George Street, King George and Ben Yehuda Streets, and Ben Yehuda Street and Jaffa Road (the latter known as [[Zion Square]]). From the mid-1940s through the 1960s, the Triangle was the commercial and cultural heart of Jerusalem, with many upscale shops and restaurants operated by [[German-Jewish]] immigrant businessmen that appealed to an affluent clientele. Following the [[reunification of Jerusalem]] in 1967 and the expansion of the city away from the downtown core, the commercial viability of the Triangle declined. The area was revitalized by the conversion of Ben Yehuda Street and the interior streets of the Triangle to an [[pedestrian zone|open-air pedestrian mall]] in 1982. Over the next two decades, outdoor cafes and souvenir shops moved in, cementing the reputation of the Triangle as a popular shopping and entertainment venue for tourists and young Israelis. ==History== [[File:Ixim 1924.jpg|200px|right|thumb|Intersection of [[King George Street (Jerusalem)|King George Street]] (foreground), [[Straus Street]] (background), and [[Jaffa Road]] (right and left), 1924.]] Before the [[Mandatory Palestine|British Mandatory government]] took over in 1917, the main commercial district in Jerusalem was in the [[Old City (Jerusalem)|Old City]]. With an eye to the continuing development of new neighborhoods outside the [[Walls of Jerusalem|Old City Walls]], the British drew up a master [[Urban planning|town plan]] that called for the establishment of two commercial hubs in the New City. The first commercial district to be built was the Downtown Triangle, although it was intended to play a secondary role to the other planned commercial district in the [[Mamilla]] area, which was closer to the Old City. However, the Mamilla development did not garner as much interest as the Triangle.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KzOAxmHDzHUC&pg=PA153 |title=Jerusalem and Its Environs: Quarters, Neighborhoods, Villages, 1800–1948|first1=Ruth|last1=Kark|first2=Michal|last2=Oren-Nordheim |publisher=Wayne State University Press|year=2001|isbn=0814329098|pages=153–156}} The land used for the Downtown Triangle had been purchased by the [[Jewish Colonization Association]] from the [[Greek Orthodox Church of Jerusalem|Greek Orthodox Patriarchate]],{{cite book |last=Wager|first=Eliyahu|year=1988|title=Illustrated Guide To Jerusalem|publisher=Jerusalem Publishing House|isbn=0875592309|page=227}} which began selling off some of its holdings in Jerusalem after World War I.{{cite web |url=http://www.biu.ac.il/js/rennert/history_12.html|title=The British Mandate|first=David|last=Eisenstadt|date=May 1997|publisher=Ingeborg Rennert Center for Jerusalem Studies|accessdate=24 November 2013}} The British developed the field into a triangular district (hence its appellation, "The Triangle") demarcated by Jaffa Road, Ben Yehuda Street (constructed by the British in 1922) and King George Street (constructed by the British in 1924). Lots were sold to large companies and cooperatives as well as private businesses. Other streets adjacent to the Triangle – Shlomzion Hamalka, Mamilla, Agron, and King David Streets – were zoned for commercial and residential use. ===European ambience=== [[File:KikarZion.jpg|200px|right|thumb|Cafe Europe, located in the Sansur Building at [[Zion Square]], circa 1934–1946.]] According to Jerusalem architectural historian [[David Kroyanker]], the heyday of the Downtown Triangle lasted from the early 1930s to the 1970s. Many stores and restaurants were opened by [[History of the Jews in Germany|German Jewish]] immigrants who sought to recreate a European ambience in the city center. Their upscale [[boutique]]s, [[coffeehouse]]s, [[delicatessen]]s, and exclusive restaurants were frequented by senior Mandate officials and wealthy, English-speaking tourists.{{cite web |url=http://www.haaretz.com/weekend/week-s-end/a-yearning-free-of-illusions-1.390958|title=A Yearning Free of Illusions|first=Noam|last=Dvir|date=19 October 2011|accessdate=24 November 2013|work=[[Haaretz]]}}{{cite web |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/hamans-hat-life-in-the-jerusalem-triangle/|title=Haman's Hat: Life in the Jerusalem Triangle|first1=Aviva|last1=Bar-Am|first2=Shmuel|last2=Bar-Am|work=[[The Times of Israel]] |date=24 August 2013|accessdate=24 November 2013}} Unlike Israeli stores that sold all kinds of unrelated products under one roof, the Europeans introduced boutiques that featured only one item, such as gloves or ties. Some shops offered unique extras, such as coffeehouses that included an orchestra and dance floor, and a bookstore with a second-floor library.{{cite web |url=http://www.nrg.co.il/online/54/ART2/284/157.html|script-title=he:פעם היה פה שמח: געגועים למשולש הזהב של ירושלים|trans-title=Once It Was Happy Here: Nostalgia for the golden triangle of Jerusalem|language=Hebrew|first=Hailit|last=Kreusa-Israel|date=12 September 2011|accessdate=24 November 2013|work=[[Maariv (newspaper)|Maariv]]}} The European immigrant-owned bookstores fueled the demand for [[detective fiction]], historical reading, and periodicals from Germany and England. [[Steimatzky]], which opened its first bookstore on Jaffa Road in the Triangle in 1925, identified the growing taste for imported newspapers and magazines and bought the franchises for many of them. The European immigrants also created a market for [[cold cut]]s and cheeses, with three competing delicatessens on King George and Ben Yehuda Streets. For many years, the Triangle was also the only place where Jerusalem residents could purchase clothing, shoes, furniture, and household goods. At its peak, the district was home to 14 cinemas screening the newest [[Hollywood]] fare. Located in close proximity to one another, the cinemas would attract both adults and youth, who would afterwards patronize the coffeehouses and restaurants. The Downtown Triangle was the cultural heart of the city and the place "to see and be seen".{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-198546328.html |title=The Internal Triangle|first=Peggy|last=Cidor|work=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |date=23 September 2011|accessdate=24 November 2013}} (subscription) ===Architecture=== The cosmopolitan flavor of the Triangle extended to its buildings. The Sansur building, for example, has an "eclectic" design that combines "[[Renaissance Revival architecture|neo-Renaissance]] and [[Classicism#In architecture|classicist]] elements".{{cite web |url=http://en.ildc.co.il/snasur.aspx|title=Sansur Building|publisher=[[Israel Land Development Company]]|accessdate=28 November 2013}} Approximately 15 buildings in the Triangle were designed by architect Reuven Avraham Rabinowitz, who often added a row of [[Stonemasonry#Types of stonemasonry|roughly dressed stone]] to the facade to demarcate each story. ==Decline and rebirth== [[File:Ben Yehuda Street pedestrian mall.jpg|200px|thumb|left|[[Ben Yehuda Street (Jerusalem)|Ben Yehuda Street]] pedestrian mall]] Following the reunification of Jerusalem in 1967, the city embarked on significant expansion. Large commercial centers were opened in the new, outlying neighborhoods of [[Talpiot]], [[Givat Shaul]], and [[Malha]], drawing customers away from the city center. Government offices began moving out as well, precipitating the economic decline of the Downtown Triangle in the 1970s.{{cite web |url=http://www.jiis.org/.upload/merkaz%20-%20english.pdf|title=Downtown Jerusalem: The story of Jerusalem's city center and its regeneration|first1=Amnon|last1=Ramon|first2=Aviel|last2=Yelinek|first3=Asaf |last3=Vitman |year=2011|accessdate=24 November 2013|publisher=[[Jerusalem Institute for Israel Studies]]|page=5}} The clientele of the upscale European boutiques had also aged, and the neighborhoods adjacent to downtown became occupied by poor and [[Haredi Judaism|Haredi]] Jews who did not patronize the Triangle. The elegant shops gave way to [[hummus]] restaurants, [[Variety store|dollar stores]], and [[money changer]]s. The advent of television precipitated the closure of most of the Triangle's cinemas. {{Quote box |width=280px |align=right |quoted=true |bgcolor=#c6dbf7 |salign=right |quote=The downtown triangle of streets is seething with Jews—
Loud, chattering geniuses, drivers, merchants, and kids,
Pharmacists from Germany, scholars,
[[Kibbutzniks]] on a spree, saints,
Men shaking in [[yarmulka]]s over a Coke,
The round and the blind, the muscle-bulging
Of our people, foaming beggars,
And open-shirted name-brand macho [[Sabra (person)|Sabra]] men. |source=—[[Danny Siegel]]{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=40F84qW2OdUC&pg=PA147 |title=A Dream of Zion: American Jews Reflect on Why Israel Matters to Them|first=Jeffrey K. |last=Salkin|year=2009|publisher=Jewish Lights Publishing|page=147|isbn=1580234151}} }} In 1982, the city attempted to revitalize the downtown district by closing Ben Yehuda Street and the Triangle's interior streets (Luncz, Dorot Rishonim, Yavetz, Ben Hillel, and HaHistadrut Streets) to traffic, and converting the entire area to an open-air [[pedestrian mall]]. Though taxi companies demonstrated against the renovation and merchants claimed it would fail, the idea proved successful. Outdoor cafes, pizzerias, and fast-food restaurants moved into the Triangle, together with shops selling souvenirs, Judaica, and jewelry to tourists.{{cite web|url=http://www.frommers.com/destinations/jerusalem/717289|title=Neighborhoods in Brief|publisher=[[Frommers]]|year=2013|accessdate=24 November 2013}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yZvTLDOgc1EC&pg=PA10 |title=Jerusalem, Jerusalem: How the Ancient City Ignited Our Modern World|first=James|last=Carroll|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt|year=2011|isbn= 0547549059|page=10}}{{cite web |url=http://www.haaretz.com/weekend/week-s-end/a-new-consumer-shrine-1.384833|title=A New Consumer Shrine?|first=Noam|last=Dvir|work=Haaretz|date=16 September 2011|accessdate=24 November 2013}} [[Street performance|Street musicians]], [[street artist]]s, political promoters, and tables manned by [[Chabad]] and [[Breslov (Hasidic group)|Breslov]] [[Hasidic Judaism|Hasidim]] add to the lively nature of the mall.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2Q4Q0jP8jxAC&pg=PA102|title=Cities in a Time of Terror: Space, Territory, and Local Resilience|first=H. V. |last=Savitch|year=2007|publisher=M.E. Sharpe|isbn=076563760X|pages=102–103}}{{cite web |url=http://www.gojerusalem.com/discover/item_64/Ben-Yehuda-Street|title=Ben Yehuda Street|publisher=Go Jerusalem|accessdate=24 November 2013}} The pedestrian mall restored the Triangle's reputation as the "heart" of the city, although the formerly upscale, European tone was replaced by a more populist image. The introduction of the [[Jerusalem Light Rail]] in December 2011 further increased local and visitor traffic: estimates show that 36,000 pedestrians per day visited the Triangle in April 2012, up from 16,000 per day in April 2004.{{cite web |url=http://www.hadassahmagazine.org/site/apps/nlnet/content.aspx?c=twI6LmN7IzF&b=5698173&ct=12960355|title=Jerusalem on Track|first=Esther|last=Hecht|date=12 February 2013|accessdate=24 November 2013|work=[[Hadassah#Hadassah Magazine|Hadassah Magazine]]}} The mall is especially busy on Saturday nights, as eateries that have closed for [[Shabbat]] reopen and the streets are crowded with young Israelis from Jerusalem and Tel Aviv. Beginning in the late 1990s, the pedestrian mall became noted for hosting a growing presence of at-risk and homeless youth. Three youth centers – Hameshulash, Hezroni's Squat, and The Zone – operate in the vicinity of Zion Square.{{cite web |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3411265,00.html|title=Square-Dwelling Youths|date=6 December 2007 |first=Yael|last=Ivri|work=[[Ynetnews]]|accessdate=24 November 2013}} ===Bombing attacks=== {{main|Ben Yehuda Street bombings}} [[File:Ben Yehuda 1948 - 2.jpg|thumb|225px|Car bombs explode on Ben Yehuda Street, 22 February 1948]] Due to its centrality and large concentration of visitors and entertainment venues, the Downtown Triangle has been the target of numerous bombing attacks and attempted attacks. On 22 February 1948, three British Army trucks led by an armored car driven by Arab irregulars and British deserters exploded on Ben Yehuda Street, killing 58 Jewish civilians and injuring 140.{{cite book |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=qCRPDVje7WwC |pages=191–193|first1=Larry|last1=Collins|first2=Dominique |last2=Lapierre|authorlink1=Larry Collins (writer)|authorlink2=Dominique Lapierre|title=O Jerusalem|year=2007|edition=reprint|publisher=Simon & Schuster|isbn=1416556273}} On 4 July 1975, a refrigerator containing {{convert|5|kg}} of explosives [[Zion Square refrigerator bombing|detonated in Zion Square]], killing 15 and wounding 77.{{cite web |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/features/a-short-history-of-terror-1.76345|title=A Short History of Terror|first=Yair|last=Sheleg|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=3 December 2001|accessdate=11 August 2014}}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TRc9ea_CKOUC&pg=RA1-PA363 |title=Israel and the Palestinian Territories|first1=Daniel|last1=Jacobs|first2=Shirley|last2=Eber|first3=Francesca |last3=Silvani|year=1998|publisher=Rough Guides|isbn=1858282489|page=363}} On 24 March 1979, a bomb exploded in a trash can in Zion Square, killing one and wounding 13. During the [[Suicide attack|suicide bomber]] era in the late 1990s, three suicide bombers stationed at different points on Ben Yehuda Street exploded themselves almost simultaneously, causing eight deaths and 277 injuries. A similar "relay" bombing attack took place on 1 December 2001: Police and emergency medical personnel were rushing to the scene of a double suicide bombing attack in the Triangle when a car bomb exploded; 20 died and 150 were wounded. Earlier, in August, a Sbarro restaurant at the corner of Jaffa Road and King George Street, packed with lunchtime customers,{{cite web |url=http://www.kerenmalki.org/Sbarro_Massacre.htm|title= The massacre at the Sbarro restaurant|year=2014|accessdate=11 August 2014|publisher=The Malki Foundation}} was bombed; 15 people died and 90 were wounded. In February 2014, in response to lobbying by terror victims groups,{{cite web |url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/Flash.aspx/287658#.U-k58vmSyv0|title=Memorial Plaque Unveiled for Israel's Worst Car Bombing|date=20 February 2014|accessdate=11 August 2014|work=[[Arutz Sheva|Israel National News]]}} the Jerusalem municipality held a ceremony and mounted a memorial plaque at the site of the 1948 bombing on Ben Yehuda Street.{{cite web |url=http://www.vosizneias.com/156017/2014/02/21/jerusalem-ceremony-and-memorial-plaque-honors-victims-of-1948s-worst-ever-israeli-car-bombing/|title= Jerusalem - Ceremony And Memorial Plaque Honors Victims Of 1948's Worst-Ever Israeli Car Bombing|first=Glen|last=Silver|date=21 February 2014|accessdate=11 August 2014|work=[[Vosizneias]]}} ==Landmarks== [[File:Zion Square 2013 mashbir.JPG|200px|right|thumb|[[Hamashbir Lazarchan]] department store at [[Zion Square]].]] [[File:Freimann & Bein, Jerusalem.jpg|200px|right|thumb|Freimann & Bein shoe store on Jaffa Road]] The tallest building in the Triangle is the seven-story, {{convert|5000|sqm}} '''[[Hamashbir Lazarchan]]''' [[department store]], which opened on the eastern side of Zion Square in 2011. It is the largest department store in Israel and the [[Flagship#Retailing|flagship store]] of the 38-store chain. Hamashbir is intimately associated with the Downtown Triangle, as the first Hamashbir store was established across the street from its current location in 1947, and moved to another vertex of the Triangle, at King George and Ben Yehuda Streets, from 1970 to 2010.{{cite web |url=http://m.jpost.com/HomePage/FrontPage/Article.aspx?id=91244045&cat=1|title=J'lem: Landmark Hamashbir dept. store gets new location|first=Greer Fay|last=Cashman|work=The Jerusalem Post|date=2 November 2011|accessdate=24 November 2013}} '''Freimann and Bein''' (50 Jaffa Road) was the first luxury shoe store in Israel. Founded by German-Jewish immigrants, it imported quality leather shoes from Europe and attracted a clientele of British officers and Arab sheikhs.{{cite web |url=http://www.nrg.co.il/online/21/ART2/319/114.html|script-title=he:באלה הידיים: גלגולם של העסקים הקטנים|trans-title=With These Hands: Incarnations of Small Businesses|language=Hebrew |first=Michal |last=Toussia Cohen|date=23 December 2011|accessdate=24 November 2013|work=Maariv}} The store originally opened in the [[Generali Building]] further east on Jaffa Road in 1935{{cite web |url= http://www.malon.co.il/article.aspx?id=23932|script-title=he:בית ג'נראלי (חברת אחריות ג'נרלי ) רחוב יפו פינת רחוב שלומציון 1|language=Hebrew|trans-title=Generali Building (Generali Insurance Company), Jaffa Road at 1 Shlomzion Street|publisher=malon.co.il|accessdate=14 August 2014}} and moved to 50 Jaffa Road in 1947. It closed in 2014. '''Khalifa Shoes''' (44 Jaffa Road), founded in 1954, is a Jewish family-owned business specializing in Israeli-made shoes and sandals.{{cite web |url=http://www.hadassahmagazine.org/site/apps/nlnet/content.aspx?c=twI6LmN7IzF&b=5698173&ct=8439817|title=For All Walks of Life|first=Barbara|last=Sofer|date=14 June 2010|accessdate=24 November 2013|work=Hadassah Magazine}} The longest-lasting dining establishments in the Triangle were '''Atara Cafe''' and '''Fink's Bar'''. Atara Cafe operated at 7 Ben Yehuda Street from 1938 to 1996. The European-style coffeehouse was a favorite of Mandate officers, pre-state paramilitary groups, and Israeli politicians, journalists, and bohemians.{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-09-27/news/ls-47891_1_landmark-cafe|title=The Final Days of a Landmark Cafe|first=Marjorie|last=Miller|date=27 September 1996|accessdate=30 November 2013|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]}}{{cite web |url=http://www.jpost.com/LifeStyle/Food-And-Wine/Cafe-Talk-Where-Atara-once-stood-318557 |title=The Final Days of a Landmark Cafe|first=Greer Fay|last=Cashman|date=3 July 2013|accessdate=30 November 2013|work=The Jerusalem Post}} Fink's Bar, at the corner of King George and HaHistadrut Streets, was open from 1936 to 2006. The intimate, exclusive restaurant was one of the most prestigious dining addresses in Jerusalem. Specializing in European cuisine, the restaurant/bar made its kitchen [[Kashrut|kosher]] in 2003 in order to overcome several years of declining business and broaden its customer base beyond "politicians, journalists and diplomats".{{cite web |url=http://www.haaretz.com/life/culture/food-wine/newly-kosher-jerusalem-landmark-fink-s-restaurant-widens-customer-base-1.109448|title=Newly kosher Jerusalem landmark Fink's restaurant widens customer base|first=Daphna|last=Berman|date=22 December 2003|accessdate=19 August 2014|work=Haaretz}} The Downtown Triangle includes two hotels. '''Kikar Zion Hotel''' (Zion Square Hotel), which faces Zion Square from the south, occupies the site of the former Zion Cinema that gave the square its name.{{cite web|url=http://allaboutjerusalem.com/he/article/%D7%9B%D7%99%D7%9B%D7%A8-%D7%A6%D7%99%D7%95%D7%9F-0|script-title=he:כיכר ציבורית מרכזית בליבהּ של ירושלים ומרכז העסקים הראשי |language=Hebrew|trans-title=Central public square in the heart of Jerusalem and the main business center|publisher=allaboutjerusalem.com|year=2014|accessdate=8 March 2014}} The cinema was demolished in 1972 and a high-rise building containing the Kikar Zion Hotel (on the upper floors) and a branch of [[Bank Hapoalim]] (on the lower floors) was erected. As of 2016, the hotel is being renovated for reopening as the Herbert Samuel Hotel. On the northern side of Zion Square stands the '''Jerusalem Hostel'''. This lodging opened as the Tel Aviv Hotel in 1926 and later became known as the Ron Hotel. [[Menachem Begin]] stood on one of the hotel's balconies on 3 August 1948, to announce the dissolution of the [[Irgun]] and the sign-up of his soldiers with the [[Israel Defense Forces]]. ==See also== {{Commons category|Jerusalem triangle}} *[[Ben Yehuda Street (Jerusalem)]] *[[Jaffa Road]] *[[King George Street (Jerusalem)]] *[[Zion Square]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Further reading== *{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?issn=pwAACAAJ&dq=%D7%A7%D7%A8%D7%95%D7%99%D7%90%D7%A0%D7%A7%D7%A8+%D7%94%D7%9E%D7%A9%D7%95%D7%9C%D7%A9&hl=en&sa=X&ei=eFqNUuXmJ42VhQeB9oGQDQ&redir_esc=y |script-title=he:המשולש הירושלמי: ביוגרפיה אורבנית|trans-title=The Jerusalem Triangle: An urban biography|last=Kroyanker|first=David|authorlink=David Kroyanker|year=2011 |publisher=Keter Publishing House |language=Hebrew|isbn=9650719482}} {{Neighborhoods of Jerusalem|state=collapsed}} {{coord|31|46|55.80|N|35|13|04.30|E|scale:10000_source:enwiki|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jerusalem Triangle}} [[Category:Jaffa Road]] [[Category:Neighbourhoods of Jerusalem]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Jerusalem]] [[Category:Central business districts]] [[Category:Downtown Triangle (Jerusalem) |Downtown Triangle (Jerusalem) ]]
